tossups.question: This composer embraced Christian Science in New York, where he ran into clarinetist Simeon Bellison, whose klezmer band Zimro (“ZIM-raw”) just toured the Far East and contained a string quartet and piano; Bellison sent this composer a notebook of Hebrew themes that he quickly worked into an Overture for them. Before finishing a ballet with four seasonal fairies, he extracted three piano pieces from it, including a plucky, chromatic gavotte. His Symphony No. 1 in D major, scored entirely in concert pitch, imitates (*) Haydn’s style and also includes a brief gavotte with “wrong notes.” Galina Ulanova premiered the title roles of his Cinderella and a ballet whose three suites include “Dance of the Knights” and “Death of Tybalt.” For 10 points, what composer of the “Classical Symphony” returned from exile to Soviet Russia and wrote Romeo and Juliet and Peter and the Wolf?
tossups.answer: Sergei Prokofiev (The first clue is about Overture on Hebrew Themes.) <OL, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: Deirdre McCloskey critiqued the tendency of people in this profession to equate statistical significance with scientific significance. A scholar in this profession studied the Mariel Boatlift using difference-in-differences analysis. This profession’s use of targets and instruments was pioneered by Jan Tinbergen (“yahn TIN-bairg-in”). Its practitioners often get their data from a nonprofit named for it, the (*) NBER. Empirical rules developed by this profession include Okun’s law, which can be explained by a multiplier effect. Techniques like variable autoregression are used in a discipline whose name is a portmanteau of this profession and “metrics.” Paul Samuelson wrote a popular textbook for studying, for 10 points, what profession of Paul Krugman?
tossups.answer: economists [or economics; or econometricians or econometrics; prompt on social scientists or word forms; prompt on academics or professors or quants] <AA, Social Science: Econ>

tossups.question: This city was the center of a movement of squatters who took over the property of former state-owned enterprises in the 1990s and formed collectives like Tacheles (“TA-khuh-liss”) in its Mitte (“MIT-uh”) neighborhood. This city’s first gay mayor coined a slogan referring to it as “poor but sexy.” A popular shopping district in this city is known by the shortened name “Ku’damm” (“KOO-dom”). Two bordering neighborhoods lend their names to a nightclub in this city called Berghain (“BAIRG-hyne”). A huge (*) concrete cylinder in this city was built to test whether its swampy soil on the river Spree could support a triumphal arch, as part of Albert Speer’s plan to turn it into a “world capital.” This city’s Tempelhof Field was converted to a park after this city’s airport relocated to Tegel (“TAY-gull”). For 10 points, name this city whose East and West halves were reunited in 1990.
tossups.answer: Berlin [accept East Berlin] <JM, Geography>

tossups.question: After the protagonist of this novel has sex with his love interest, whom he calls his “little rabbit,” he asks her “did thee feel the earth move?” This novel begins as it ends, with the protagonist lying on the “pine needle floor of the forest,” as he waits to kill a Catholic lieutenant. One part of this novel centers on the Russian journalist Karkov, while another part is told from the perspective of a leader who dies defending a hilltop named (*) El Sordo. The protagonist of this novel strikes up a relationship with a submissive woman who was recently assaulted shortly after having his palms read by Pilar. After some detonators are thrown down a gorge by Pablo, the protagonist of this novel is forced to use grenades to blow up a bridge. Robert Jordan joins a guerilla group in, for 10 points, what Ernest Hemingway novel set during the Spanish Civil War?
tossups.answer: For Whom the Bell Tolls <ML, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: Studies of Pel enhancer fragility in these animals were used to investigate the loss of pelvic structures. Males of a certain type of these animals have carotenoid-based pigment cells called “egg spots.” Males of one type of this animal court females with swollen bellies that perform a zig-zag dance, but attack other males with red bellies. Niko Tinbergen studied behaviors consistent throughout a species that always run to completion, or (*) fixed action patterns, in these animals. Adaptive radiation was studied with over two hundred species of one of these animals in Lake Tanganyika. These animals can maintain their buoyancy using a swim bladder. Sticklebacks and cichlids (“SICK-lids”) are examples of, for 10 points, what vertebrates that travel in schools?
tossups.answer: fish [accept sticklebacks or Gasterosteidae or cichlids or ciclidae or cichliformes until read] <JZ, Biology: EEB>

tossups.question: The post office robber George Wilson was executed after refusing a pardon from this president. Under this president’s administration, one man was arrested after collaborating with Elias Boudinot (“uh-LIE-us boo-DIN-ott”) on a translation of the Bible. Arthur Schlesinger won his first Pulitzer Prize for a book about this president. After Thomas Hart (*) Benton vehemently (“VEE-uh-mint-lee”) denied rumors that this president would appoint him to the Supreme Court, this president appointed Roger Taney (“TAW-nee”) instead. This president said “John Marshall has made his decision; now let him enforce it” after a case in which state jurisdiction over Cherokee land was challenged. That case during this president’s tenure was Worcester v. Georgia. For 10 points, name this president under whom the Indian Removal Act was passed, leading to the Trail of Tears.
tossups.answer: Andrew Jackson [prompt on Old Hickory] <ML, US History>

tossups.question: Soga no Hitoshi’s membership in this profession led his uncle, Umako, to promote its growth. According to a historical legend, no woman became sole empress of Japan from 770 to 1629 due to Empress Kōken’s affair with a man of this occupation named Dōkyo. Men of this [emphasize] primary profession known as sōhei made a base at Enryaku-ji (“EN-ryah-koo-JEE”), from which they assaulted Kyoto. Those men of this profession were later besieged at Mount Hiei (“HEE-ay”) by (*) Oda Nobunaga. Practitioners of this profession included Dōgen and Nichiren, the latter of whom inspired the Soka Gakkai movement. A Meiji-era law allowed Japanese members of this occupation to eat meat and marry, partly to weaken them relative to their Shintō counterparts. For 10 points, name these religious figures who propagated sects like Zen across Japan.
tossups.answer: Buddhist monks [or Buddhist priests; or Buddhist clergy; or equivalents; or sōhei or monshu or bettō or juji or jushoku; accept Zen in place of “Buddhist” until read; prompt on monks or priests or clergy or equivalents by asking “from what religion?”; do not accept or prompt on religious figures from any other religion] <AA, World History>

tossups.question: This painting was inspired by one on the same theme by Peter Paul Rubens that shows three stars above the title figure, who carries a scythe in his right hand. Before Baron Émile d’Erlanger (“ay-MEEL dair-lawn-ZHAY”) had this painting transferred from plaster to canvas, it was in a room with paintings of Judith and Holofernes, a witches’ sabbath, and the artist’s mistress, surnamed Weiss (“vice”). This painting was the direct inspiration for the Pale Man in the film (*) Pan’s Labyrinth. It was originally found opposite La Leocadia (“lay-oh-KAH-dee-ah”) in the artist’s house, the Quinta del Sordo (“KEEN-tah del SOR-doh”). This painting shows a wide-eyed giant against a black background holding up a bloodied, headless corpse. For 10 points, what grotesque painting by Francisco Goya shows the title Roman god eating one of his children?
tossups.answer: Saturn Devouring His Son [or Saturn Devouring His Children or Saturno devorando a su hijo] <WA, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: This scientist is the alphabetically-last namesake of a method to calculate potential energy curves for diatomic atoms from their rotational–vibrational spectra along with Klein and Rees. An exotic state of matter in which a large atom contains smaller atoms in between its nucleus and electrons is known as this scientist’s polaron. Helium 2-plus is the first known example of one of this man’s (*) molecules, which have high principal quantum numbers. His constant of roughly 1.09 times 10-to-the-7 inverse meters is used to calculate the wavelengths of the Balmer and Lyman series. His namesake equation relates the initial and final energy levels of an atomic transition to its emitted wavelength. For 10 points, name this physicist who developed an equation used to calculate the wavelengths of light emitted by energy level changes in the hydrogen atom.
tossups.answer: Johannes Rydberg [accept Rydberg equation or Rydberg constant or Rydberg polaron] <RN, Physics>

tossups.question: This action titles a collection’s opening poem, whose speaker “[utters] the word Democratic, the word En-Masse.” A poem titled for this action parenthetically notes “The universe is a procession with measured and perfect motion” and recounts how a man’s body “runs [with] / The same old blood! the same red-running blood!” The final section of a poem titled for this activity concludes “O I say now these are the (*) soul!” A poem’s opening declaration of this activity is followed by the line “The armies of those I love engirth me and I engirth them.” This action is performed by mechanics, a carpenter, and a boatman in a poem that likely inspired Langston Hughes’ poem “I, Too” and describes hearing America doing it. For 10 points, a poem by Walt Whitman uses what action to extol the “Body Electric?”
tossups.answer: singing [accept “One’s Self I Sing” or “I Sing the Body Electric” or “I Hear America Singing”] <RK, Poetry>

tossups.question: This island’s only ever king was a German mercenary who ruled for only seven months in 1736, later tried to mortgage it to British creditors, and was named Theodor von Neuhoff. Female suffrage was implemented on this island by the constitution of its namesake republic, which was declared in 1755 and issued coins depicting its traditional Moor’s Head symbol. That republic ended this island’s longstanding control by the city of (*) Genoa and was led by Pasquale Paioli (“pa-SKWAH-lay pie-OH-lee”) until it was conquered by the troops of Louis XV in 1769. This island’s most famous resident, born in that same year, executed a coup on the Eighteenth Brumaire and issued a namesake “code” reforming French law. Napoleon Bonaparte was born on, for 10 points, what Mediterranean island controlled by France, a smaller neighbor of Sardinia?
tossups.answer: Corsica [or Corse] <WA, European History>

tossups.question: Merchants would dress a slave up and have him impersonate this god for forty days prior to this god’s festival. A wingspan of more than 10 meters was possessed by a giant pterosaur (“TAIR-oh-saur”) named for this god from the late Cretaceous Period. This god stole cacao beans from his brother, after which he taught the secrets of making chocolate to humanity, which he earlier created after going to the underworld and stealing jade (*) bones. This god immolated himself and became the planet Venus after sleeping with his sister. He was often personified as a man with white skin and hair who sailed away to the east on a raft of snakes and is the twin of the dog-headed Xolotl (“sho-LO-tull”). Hernán Cortés may have been confused by some Aztecs with, for 10 points, what Aztec feathered serpent?
tossups.answer: Quetzalcoatl <WA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: Near the opening of this story, the protagonist says “Hark at the wind” to try and distract his son during a game of chess that he eventually loses. Towards the end of this story, the protagonist lies to his wife that a rat caused the sound of the persistent knocking at the door. In this story, a woman states “Sounds like the ‘Arabian Nights’” shortly after her husband retrieves an object thrown by Sergeant-Major Morris into a fire. After his (*) son Herbert is caught in some machinery and dies, this story’s protagonist learns that he will receive the 200 pounds he had previously requested. In this story, an “old Fakir” puts a spell on an object that supposedly grants a person three wishes. For 10 points, name this horror story by W. W. Jacobs titled for the cursed appendage of a primate.
tossups.answer: “The Monkey’s Paw” <RK, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: The Osogbo sacred grove in Nigeria is home to several mysterious sculptures made of this material with human faces. On his tobacco farm, art dealer Tom Blomefield established a workshop to train artists using this material, including Henry Munyaradzi (“moon-ya-RA-dzee”), an important figure in the “Shona” school. Many African artworks were made of the “tiger’s eye” variety of this material. Churches in the (*) Ethiopian city of Lalibela are built from single pieces of this material. Another variety of this material was used to make the bird statues found at Great Zimbabwe. In ancient Egypt, this material was used to create the complex at Abu Simbel and to produce massive obelisks. For 10 points, name this material used to build “monolithic” pieces of art.
tossups.answer: stone [accept rock or soapstone or sandstone or quartz] <JM, Other Arts: Architecture>

tossups.question: According to Arabic legend, a symbol resembling these objects appeared on a legendary signet ring that was signed with God’s name. A still-extant Gnostic religion uses one of these objects to collectively symbolize the metaphysical tenets of the mind, the soul, the word, the precedent, and the antecedent, known as the khams ḥudūd (“hoo-DOOD”). On the ringstone symbol, one of these objects represents the Báb. A multicolored one of these objects is a symbol of a faith whose prophet was Jethro of Midian, the highly (*) secretive Druze (“drooz”). The Bahá’í religion is also represented by one of these symbols. The flags of Pakistan and the Nation of Islam pair this symbol with the crescent moon. For 10 points, what celestial objects include a namesake “Shield of David” in Judaism?
tossups.answer: stars [accept five-pointed star or nineteen-pointed star; accept pentagram; accept Star of David; accept hexagram] <AA, Religion>

tossups.question: An R-module Q has this property if every homomorphism out of a left ideal of R into Q can be extended to all of R, according to Baer’s criterion. In the short exact sequence consisting of maps from 0 to A to B to C to 0, the map from A to B has this property. To prove that a homomorphism has this property, f-of-x is set equal to f-of-y and it is shown that x must equal y. If m is greater than n, then a linear transformation from Rm to Rn (*) cannot have this property, which is equivalent to having a trivial kernel. A surjective map with this property is bijective. This property is required for an inverse function to have a unique output for every input. The function x-squared does not have this property because its graph fails the horizontal line test. For 10 points, name this property in which each output of a function is reached from exactly one input.
tossups.answer: injective [or one-to-one or injection] <NC, Math>

tossups.question: Both a 2011 debut novel by Madeline Miller and Pat Barker’s 2018 novel The Silence of the Girls are inspired by this work, which was translated in 2015 by Caroline Alexander. Sitting Bull’s secretary Catherine Weldon appears in a retelling of this work in which a beautiful woman flaunts a yellow dress stolen from the wife of a Major who owns a pig farm. A stand-in for this work’s author named Seven Seas sings “African babble” at Ma Kilman’s (*) No Pain Café in a retelling of it set on St. Lucia (“LOO-sha”) by Derek Walcott. The first-known use of ekphrasis was this poem’s description of a warrior’s shield. The Catalogue of Ships appears in this epic poem, which opens by describing the “black and murderous” rage of Achilles. For 10 points, the Trojan War is the subject of what Homeric epic?
tossups.answer: Iliad (Madeline Miller’s novel is The Song of Achilles.) <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: EGLN proteins catalyze the addition of this functional group onto HIF-1alpha to mark it for ubiquitination. Triethylaluminum catalyzes the oligomerization of ethylene in a process used to produce fatty versions of this functional group named for Ziegler. Cumene hydroperoxide undergoes a Hock rearrangement in an industrial process used to add this functional group to (*) benzene. This functional group has a broad IR peak at 3000 inverse centimeters due to hydrogen bonding. Pyridinium chlorochromate can be used instead of a Jones reagent when one wishes to oxidize this functional group into an aldehyde instead of a carboxylic acid. For 10 points, name this functional group written as OH.
tossups.answer: hydroxyl [or alcohol; accept fatty alcohol or Ziegler alcohol] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: A businessman based in this colony, Alfred Beit, co-founded a company whose interests led to this colony’s annexation of Stellaland. This colony’s forces fared rather poorly when its opponents actually had effective firearms at the Battle of Qalabani during the so-called “Gun War,” which helped bring about the censoring of Henry Bartle Frere (“freer”). A man based in this colony won the largely fraudulent Rudd Concession from Lobengula. Discrimination against (*) settlers from this colony led some of its residents to launch an abortive coup called the Jameson Raid against the government of Paul Kruger. Those settlers from this colony, called Uitlanders (“OUT-land-ers”), flocked to the Witwatersrand (“vit-VOT-ers-ROND”) at the encouragement of Cecil Rhodes. For 10 points, name this colony that was unified with the Boer Republics into a modern-day country.
tossups.answer: Cape Colony [or Cape of Good Hope; or British South Africa] <ML, Commonwealth/Misc>

tossups.question: This man names a technique used in data analysis that finds an optimal set of transformations for different “shapes” that minimizes the least-squares distance between them. He also names a 2010 book of aphorisms that advocates classical values, as against the “phoniness, nerdiness, and philistinism” of modernity, written by Nassim Taleb. The myth about this man from Eleusis is often analogized to the Eurozone, which employs only (*) one monetary policy for all people. This mythical man offered hospitality to visitors, but then used his skills as a smith to maim them, until he was killed by a king journeying to his home city of Athens. The last bandit killed by Theseus was, for 10 points, what man who stretched victims or chopped their limbs off to make them fit in his bed?
tossups.answer: Procrustes (“pro-CRUSS-teez”) [accept Procrustean bed or Procrustean analysis or The Bed of Procrustes; prompt on Damastes] <WA, Other Academic>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: Arguments against attempts to “renew” these places are presented in a book by Jane Jacobs about the “life and death” of “Great American” ones. For 10 points each:
answers: cities [accept city or urban areas, locations, renewal, etc.]
Le Corbusier (“luh cor-booz-YAY”)
William Whyte (That book is The Organization Man.) <WA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>
parts: Give these locations that are often modeled as concentric zones around a central business district.

Jacobs also criticized this theorist, whose concept of a “radiant city” was the inspiration for the design of Chandigarh (“CHON-dee-gar”). In a treatise, this theorist advocates for roof gardens and the use of pilotis.

This sociologist invited Jacobs to contribute essays to Fortune magazine, after which the essays were added to the book Exploding Metropolis. Earlier, Fortune sponsored interviews of CEOs for this sociologist’s best-known book, which studies conformity in large companies in the 1950s.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about US overseas operations involving the Night Stalker unit. For 10 points each:
answers: helicopter [accept MI-24 or MI-25]
Osama bin Laden [accept Usama bin Mohammed bin Awad bin Laden]
Black Hawk [accept Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk] <ML, US History>
parts: In Operation Mount Hope III, the Night Stalkers captured a vehicle of this type made by the Soviet MIL plant. A force of this type of vehicle failed to achieve its objective in Operation Eagle Claw, leading to the creation of the Night Stalkers.

The Night Stalker unit was the airborne arm of the three-pronged attack in the operation to kill this man. This leader of al-Qaeda played a key role in planning 9/11 before being killed in 2011 in Abbottabad, Pakistan.

The Night Stalkers fought in a battle against Mohamed Farah Aidid’s forces in Mogadishu after two of this type of helicopter were shot down. This type of helicopter gives its name to a book by Mark Bowden about the event.

bonuses.leadin: In one episode of this ongoing issue, Daniel Korstvedt claimed that photographs from a biography by Robert Haas had misled the scholar Deryck Cooke into believing that a fake manuscript existed. For 10 points each:
answers: Bruckner problem [or answers about there being many editions or revisions or versions or changes of Anton Bruckner’s symphonies or music; or authenticity of Bruckner’s symphonies; prompt on similar answers, such as Bruckner’s insecurity or his symphonies being incomplete or unfinished or drafts or sketches]
Vienna Philharmonic [or VPO or Wiener Philharmoniker; prompt on Vienna orchestra or Wien]
four [accept Symphony No. 4] <WA, Classical/Opera>
parts: Identify or describe this persistent issue in musicology that Haas and Leopold Nowak escalated by creating multiple arrangements of a certain composer’s Symphony No. 8 in C minor, which uses a duplet-triplet rhythm.

This orchestra, which premiered Bruckner’s Symphony No. 8, has performed the Haas edition since the 1930s. In 1898, Gustav Mahler was elected conductor of this orchestra, which is in the city where he lived most of his life.
Bruckner’s most popular symphony is the “Romantic,” his symphony of this number. Johannes Brahms wrote this many symphonies, and most Romantic symphonies have his many movements.

bonuses.leadin: In drug design, “druglikeness” is a qualitative measure of how “drug-like” a molecule is based on its potency, ligand (“LIG-und”) efficiency, molecular weight, and this quantity. For 10 points each:
answers: partition coefficient [or log P]
chromatography [accept high-performance liquid chromatography; prompt on HPLC]
hydrogen bonds [or H-bonds] <RN, Chemistry>
parts: Name this quantity, equal to the difference in solubility of a compound in water and in 1-octanol (“one-octanol”), which is useful for evaluating a molecule’s distribution in the body.

A common way of measuring the partition coefficient is with the high-performance liquid version of this technique, which uses a solvent, known as the mobile phase, to separate components of a mixture.

Lipinski’s rules of 5 for “druglikeness” states that a molecule should not have more than 5 donors or 10 acceptors of these interactions. These interactions cause hydroxyl groups to have very broad peaks in IR spectra.

bonuses.leadin: In the 2018 World Cup, Tunisia’s goalkeeper faked injuries so that his teammates could catch an evening snack break, as they were practicing this observance and were really hungry. For 10 points each:
answers: Ramadan
iftar
Ramadan soap operas [or Ramadan TV shows or TV programs or TV serials] <JM, Religion>
parts: Name this Muslim month of fasting that ends on Eid al-Fitr (“EED ull-FIT-urr”).
During Ramadan, this large meal usually breaks the fast during the evening. An apricot drink called Qamr ad-Din is traditionally consumed with this meal.

In much of the Islamic world, the role of traditional post-iftar storytellers have largely been replaced by examples of these things, which are called musalsalat. Adel Emam is one of the most famous creators of them.

bonuses.leadin: This adjective names an expansion used in chemistry that expresses the pressure of a system in equilibrium through a power-law expansion. For 10 points each:
answers: virial [accept virial equation or virial expansion or virial theorem]
mass
velocity dispersion [prompt on velocity or dispersion] <WA, Astronomy>
parts: Give this adjective that names a theorem widely used in astronomy that relates the average potential and kinetic energies of a system of objects governed by conservative forces.
In astronomy, the virial theorem is often used to estimate this quantity for galaxies and clusters. The gravitational potential is given by “negative big-G, times this quantity, divided by distance.”

A simple formula for this quantity, which sets it equal to the square root of [read slowly] “mass times big-G divided by effective galactic radius,” can be derived from the virial theorem. This value, symbolized sigma, quantifies variation in the rate of movement of different objects in a cluster or galaxy.

bonuses.leadin: This thinker postulated four theories, including a “sensuous-objective theory” of the title subject, in his Letters on the Aesthetic Education of Man. For 10 points each:
answers: Friedrich von Schiller [or Johann Christoph Friedrich von Schiller]
beauty [or the beautiful; prompt on synonyms]
play [accept play drive or Spieltrieb; prompt on “Structure, Sign, and Play”] <ML, Phil/Thought>
parts: Name this German author of the Kallias letters who also wrote the play Mary Stuart.
Schiller’s letters, like a lot of aesthetics, focused on this quality. This concept, which can be defined as aesthetic appeal, is contrasted with the sublime in the works of Edmund Burke.

The Aesthetic Letters postulate a “drive” named for this concept and suggest that man is “only fully a human being” when he engages in it. In another context, Jacques Derrida suggested that this concept can manipulate signs via the “movement of supplementarity.”

bonuses.leadin: This place titles an anthology on the “Origins of North American Dropout Culture” edited by James Koehnline (“KEN-line”), and Hakim Bey cites this place as an early “temporary autonomous zone.” For 10 points each:
answers: Croatan [or Croatoan]
North Carolina
New York <JM, Historiography>
parts: Identify this place whose name was found carved on a tree by a rescue mission led by John White as the only remnant of a colony he founded. This place also names a tribe native to Ocracoke and Hatteras Island.

The Roanoke colonists and the Croatan group may have both been absorbed into the Lumbee, a tri-racial confederation based in this state, whose city of Raleigh is named for the sponsor of the Roanoke Colony.

The book Gone to Croatan describes the use of Indian disguises in uprisings like this state’s Anti-Rent War, which attacked the Patroonship system that gave families descended from this state’s early settlers, like the Rensselaers (“ren-suh-LEERS”), quasi-feudal power over their employees.

bonuses.leadin: The author of this novel tried to pass it off as an Italian manuscript translated by William Marshal. For 10 points each:
answers: The Castle of Otranto
Gothic fiction
The Monk (by Matthew Gregory Lewis) <ML, Long Fiction>
parts: Name this novel in which Father Jerome discovers that Theodore is his long-lost son. Theodore saves the princess Isabella from marrying the villainous lord Manfred at the conclusion of this novel by Horace Walpole.
The Castle of Otranto is a foremost example of this genre, whose novels were traditionally set in gloomy castles and blended elements of horror and romance
The legend of the Bleeding Nun features in this Gothic novel, in which Father Ambrosio descends into sin after being tempted by Matilda.

bonuses.leadin: This city’s namesake castle was destroyed in a 1686 siege, rebuilt as a Baroque palace, suffered several fires, extensively remodeled in the late 19th century, and gutted in the 1950s by the Communists. For 10 points each:
answers: Buda [accept Buda Castle; do not accept or prompt on “Budapest”]
Austria [or Österreich; accept Austria-Hungary]
Stephen [or István; accept Stephen’s Tower] <WA, European History>
parts: Name this city founded around that castle in 1247, directly across from a commercial hub. It was later linked to that alphabetically-later commercial twin via the Széchenyi (“SAY-chain-yee”) Chain Bridge in 1849, and finally merged with it in 1873.
Buda was merged with Pest to become the capital of the Hungarian monarchy, which at the time was unified with the monarchy of this other kingdom under Habsburg rule.

Among the oldest ruins in Buda is a tower built by a lord with this first name that blew up in 1715 when a friar shot a cannonball at it. Another Hungarian of this name received a crown from Pope Sylvester II in 1001 CE and was later canonized.

bonuses.leadin: Jez Butterworth’s 2017 play The Ferryman centers on the patriarch of a country home who is a former member of this organization. For 10 points each:
answers: IRA [or Irish Republican Army]
Abbey Theatre [or National Theatre of Ireland]
Easter Rising [or Easter Rebellion] <RK, Drama>
parts: Name this organization. The protagonist of the play The Shadow of a Gunman is mistaken for a member of this organization, gaining the affection of a woman who later hides a bag of bombs to prevent his arrest.

Sean O’Casey’s Shadow of a Gunman was premiered at this Dublin theatre, co-founded by Lady Gregory and W. B. Yeats (“yates”). Audiences rioted at its 1907 premiere of J. M. Synge’s (“sing’s”) The Playboy of the Western World.
Sean O’Casey’s play The Plough and the Stars depicts this historical event. A poem by Yeats declares “A terrible beauty is born” during this 1916 event.

bonuses.leadin: Name these Neoclassical artists, for 10 points each.
answers: Jacques-Louis David
Angelica Kauffman
Antonio Canova <AR, Painting/Sculpture>
parts: This French Neoclassical painter’s Greco-Roman works often reflected contemporary revolutionary themes, and include The Oath of the Horatii and The Intervention of the Sabine Women.

While living in London, this Neoclassical artist often allegorized fellow members of “bluestocking” circles as Muses or other classical figures. This painter’s numerous depictions of Shakespearean characters include one showing Miranda and Ferdinand in a grove.
This Italian-born Baroque sculptor, who spent most of his career in France, created such Neoclassical masterpieces as Psyche Revived by Cupid’s Kiss and Napoleon as Mars the Peacemaker.

bonuses.leadin: Name these places important to the history of rap music, for 10 points each.
answers: Compton [accept Straight Outta Compton]
New Orleans [or Nawlins or The Big Easy]
Queensbridge Houses <RN, Geography>
parts: Kendrick Lamar is one of many storied rappers to come out of this neighborhood of Los Angeles, which titles a groundbreaking album by N.W.A.

Playboi Carti’s song “Magnolia” references a public housing development located in this city, which once housed Birdman and Jay Electronica. Baby Boy da Prince and Lil Wayne are also from this southern city.

This housing complex in Long Island City, the largest in the Western Hemisphere, was home to such pioneering MCs as Marley Marl, MC Shan, and Roxanne Shante in the 1980s. In “Memory Lane (Sittin in da park),” Nas (“nozz”) raps “Now let me take a trip down memory lane / coming out of” this place.

bonuses.leadin: When alpha particles strike gold film, as in the Rutherford experiment, this quantity is proportional to the fourth power of the cosecant of the deflection angle. For 10 points each:
answers: cross section [prompt on sigma; accept differential cross section or total cross section]
scattering process [or word forms]
mean free path [prompt on lambda] <RN, Physics>
parts: Name this quantity, equal to the area required for the interaction of two particles. This quantity is usually measured in units of barns.
The cross section is the minimum area required for this sort of process to occur. This process can be thought of as one particle striking another, deviating their trajectories.

In a gas of identical particles, the cross section is equal to the reciprocal of the product of the number density and this other parameter. It equals the product of average particle velocity times the average time between collisions.

bonuses.leadin: Benjamin Moser’s 2019 biography of this author emphasizes her relationships with women like María Irene Fornés and Annie Leibovitz. For 10 points each:
answers: Susan Sontag
AIDS [or Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome; or HIV; or Human Immunodeficiency Virus; or HIV/AIDS]
Rebecca Solnit (Those essays are “Sontag and Tsunami” and “Men Explain Things to Me.”) <RK, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this author who inspired the 2019 Met Gala theme by writing an essay interspersed with Oscar Wilde quotes about the “triumph of the epicene style,” titled “Notes on ‘Camp.’”
Sontag’s story “The Way We Live Now” is mainly centered around the crisis of this disease, which is a focus of Tony Kushner’s play Angels in America.

An essay by this author begins “the news of Susan Sontag’s death arrived as a single sentence spoken in the opening moments of a radio news program.” She related being lectured on her own book River of Shadows, which is about photographer Eadweard Muybridge (“Edward MY-bridge”), in an essay that coined the term “mansplaining.”

bonuses.leadin: This technique is used for immunophenotyping of bone marrow to characterize hematologic cancers. For 10 points each:
answers: flow cytometry [do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
dead [or nonviable; accept reasonable equivalents; accept apoptotic, undergoing apoptosis, necrotic, undergoing necrosis; do not accept or prompt on “quiescent”]
mitochondria [or mitochondrion] <EM, Biology: Genetics/Cell>
parts: Name this technique in which an array of lasers is used to measure several markers at once. FACS is a form of cell sorting based on this technology.
When performing flow cytometry, cells with this property are initially excluded. Cells with this status fail to convert calcein AM to calcein and fail to exclude PI or 7-AAD.
The DiIC1(5) assay is used with flow cytometry to measure the membrane potential of this double-membraned organelle that generates ATP.

bonuses.leadin: A poem that claims to be a completion of this work begins by addressing a “Muse of the past, Divinity sublime.” For 10 points each:
answers: Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage
Lord Byron [or George Gordon Byron; or the 6th Baron Byron]
Bridge of Sighs [prompt on bridge] <ML, Poetry>
parts: Name this poem for which Alphonse de Lamartine wrote that “Last Canto.” This autobiographical narrative poem in four cantos popularized its author’s namesake “hero,” who is often rebellious or moody.
Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage was written by this Romantic poet, best known for “She Walks in Beauty.”

Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage coined this common name for a Venetian landmark, where Harold stands with “A palace and a prison on each hand.” A Thomas Hood poem about a young woman’s suicide shares its name with this structure.

bonuses.leadin: An example of this substance that had the ability to expand continuously was stolen by Gun (“gwun”) from Feather Mountain, for which he was later exiled. For 10 points each:
answers: soil [or dirt or earth or clay]
Yellow River [or Huang He]
Xia (“sh’yah”) dynasty <WA, Myths/Legends>
parts: A magical material used by Yu the Great called xirang (“shee-rong”) is an example of what substance? Please give an English answer.
Yu and Gun were thus legendarily able to stem the serious problem of this primary river of Northern China flooding and ruining the country, allowing Chinese civilization to get going.

Yu’s establishment of this oldest Chinese dynasty is described by Sima Qian (“suh-mah ch’yen”). Its history is largely considered to be mythological, though archaeology has begun to confirm its existence.

bonuses.leadin: The characteristic syncopated rhythm of this genre is [read slowly] “sixteenth, eighth, sixteenth, eighth, eighth” and can be found in such songs as “Tingalayo.” For 10 points each:
answers: calypso
Lord Kitchener [accept Dr. Kitch; or Aldwyn Roberts]
steel drum [or steel drums; or steel pan; prompt on drums or pan] <JM, Other Arts: Music>
parts: Name this genre of music that originated in Trinidad. It was syncretized with soul in the “soca” genre.
One of the most famous calypsonians is this Trinidadian musician who celebrated emigration to Britain in “London is the Place for Me” and Ghanaian independence in “The Birth of Ghana.”

Calypso is also characterized by its use of this instrument, which is often made from the severed tops of oil drums. Flattened spots on this metal instrument’s rounded surface are struck to produce different pitches.

bonuses.leadin: It’s not Vietnam, but “boat people” from this country began fleeing and arriving in the US with greater frequency after its dictatorship eradicated the creole pigs that its peasantry traditionally relied on. For 10 points each:
answers: Haiti [or Republic of Haiti; or Republique d’Haiti]
Jean-Bertrand Aristide [or Titid]
Guantanamo Bay [or Gitmo] <JM, World History>
parts: Name this country where the dictatorship of “Papa Doc” and “Baby Doc” Duvalier was supported with American aid.

After the overthrow of the Duvalier dictatorship, this defrocked radical priest dominated Haitian politics. A US intervention restored this leader to power after he was overthrown in a 1991 coup backed by the secret police of the Duvalier family.
Haitian “boat people” were held at this site, whose conditions would later be the subject of the Supreme Court cases Hamdan v. Rumsfeld and Boumedienne v. Bush.
